title: The Debacle in Afghanistan
summary: Biden and Trump share responsibility for the looming defeat.. Former Defense Secretary Bob Gates famously wrote that President Biden has been on the wrong side of every major foreign-policy issue in his long career. The world is getting another example as Mr. Biden's hell-bent, ill-planned withdrawal from Afghanistan is turning into a strategic defeat and moral debacle.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Request to Block Indiana University's Vaccine Mandate for Students
summary: Justice Amy Coney Barrett rejects emergency request in first anti-mandate college case to reach the court. WASHINGTON-Supreme Court Justice Amy Coney Barrett on Thursday rejected an emergency request by a group of Indiana University students who were seeking to block the school from enforcing a Covid-19 vaccine requirement for the coming semester.

title: Nielsen Asks to Take a Break From Key Media-Industry Seal of Approval
summary: The company requested hiatus from Media Rating Council accreditation before a council committee vote on its status. Nielsen Holdings PLC has asked the Media Rating Council, the media industry's measurement watchdog, to pause accreditation for its national TV rating service, a move that would leave the measurement giant's core product without the organization's seal of approval for the first time since the 1960s.

title: Disney Posts a Rebound as Tourists Returned to Its Theme Parks
summary: Executives note uncertainty ahead with Covid-19 Delta variant; company continued to add streaming subscribers to Disney+ and Hulu. Walt Disney Co. 's parks saw a strong rebound in visitors as people left their pandemic cocoon, but the company acknowledged uncertainty ahead because of the coronavirus Delta variant.

title: DoorDash Revenue Climbs as Consumers Stick to Food Delivery
summary: Company sees expanded offerings and delivery partnerships spurring growth amid uncertainty from Delta variant. DoorDash Inc.'s second-quarter revenue almost doubled, showing food delivery's resilience even as restaurants reopened across the U.S. and people began moving around again.

title: Covid Anxiety and Fear of the Base
summary: Americans need to be more tactful and understanding when it comes to measures like masks and vaccines.. They're all afraid of their base. That's the central fact of American political life now, that leaders of all sorts aren't leading their people but are terrified of getting crosswise with them. They're afraid of their own fans. This is true of everyone from cable anchors and hosts who know exactly who's watching and what they want, to presidents of the United States.

title: Bring on the Covid Vaccine Boosters
summary: The mask wars are a political distraction. More shots are needed.. Most of the media and political class are absorbed by the mask debate, but the Food and Drug Administration is keeping the focus where it should be: vaccines. On Thursday the agency was close to approving Covid-19 booster shots for immuno-compromised patients, and more people will need them soon.

title: Britney Spears's Father to Exit Conservatorship
summary: James Spears set to transfer control of the pop star's finances to a new conservator, court documents state. Britney Spears's father said in a new court filing he would step down at some point from the helm of the controversial conservatorship that has governed the pop star's personal life and roughly $60 million estate for the last 13 years.

title: Dumbing Oregon Down
summary: The soft bigotry of low progressive expectations for minority students.. Why didn't we think of that? Politicians and school officials in Oregon are embarrassed that too many minority children fail tests designed to confirm they've mastered the "essential skills" that high school is meant to teach. So in the name of racial equity, they've now done the progressive thing. Instead of lifting graduation rates by boosting student performance, they're eliminating the proficiency requirement.

title: How to Send U.S. Companies Overseas
summary: A new study shows how the Biden plan would hurt U.S. firms.. We know this doesn't fit the political times, but surely someone on Capitol Hill must care about what the Biden Administration's tax plans will do to the U.S. economy. Some economists are starting to do the work of figuring this out, and the results are alarming.

title: Leader of WHO Team Investigating Covid-19 Calls for Closer Look at China Lab
summary: Peter Ben Embarek says investigators should seek more information about Wuhan CDC. The Danish head of a World Health Organization-led team that traveled to China earlier this year to probe the origins of Covid-19 called for closer scrutiny of a laboratory near the site of the first known cluster of cases at a market in the central Chinese city of Wuhan.

title: Will Biden Bring an End to Reagan's Era of Prosperity?
summary: Forty years after the 1981 tax cuts, America needs to relearn the lessons of the supply-side revolution.. Friday marks the 40th anniversary of Ronald Reagan's first tax cuts-arguably the most consequential and controversial economic policy paradigm shift of the past half-century. The Reagan supply-side revolution went global. An analysis by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development found that the unweighted average top marginal income-tax rate among developed countries fell by a third, from 65% to 43%, after 25 years. Nearly every nation, from China to Costa Rica, imposes lower tax rates today than in the 1970s.

title: Covid and a Tale of Two Summer Festivals
summary: In Wisconsin, burgers are back. Butterflies will have to wait.. The 200-pound hamburger is poised to make its triumphant return in Seymour, Wis., this weekend. Twenty miles south, in Appleton, the community's annual summer release of butterflies has been postponed until next year.

title: Purdue Pharma Director Says Sacklers Required Full Release in Bankruptcy Deal
summary: Family members who own OxyContin maker would only fund multibillion-dollar settlement if they got protection from opioid lawsuits, a company director testified Thursday. The family members who own OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP required broad legal releases extinguishing opioid lawsuits against them as a condition for funding what became a roughly $4.5 billion settlement proposal, a company director testified Thursday during a bankruptcy trial examining the deal.

title: Notable & Quotable: Donald Kagan
summary: 'Universities, he proposed, are failing students and hurting American democracy.'. From the Journal's April 27, 2013, Weekend Interview with historian Donald Kagan, who died Aug. 6 at 89:

title: Social Media's Threat to Religious Freedom
summary: A theologian's talk on the Christian view of sex was deemed a 'content violation.'. Carl Trueman is a distinguished scholar, bestselling author and ordained Presbyterian minister. On Aug. 7 he gave a series of talks to the Sacramento Gospel Conference, live-streamed on the YouTube channel of Immanuel Baptist Church. Twice during the event, the live broadcast was booted off the air. Viewers were informed that the first interruption was due to a copyright violation, possibly the result of Christian music that the conference organizers played during a break. But in the second, more mysterious instance, Mr. Trueman's presentation went dark because of a "content violation."

title: Schumer and His Shadow
summary: Why is he so afraid of AOC? Ask the ghosts of Joe Crowley and Eliot Engel.. "Me and my shadow / . . . Not a soul can bust this team in two / We stick together like glue."

title: Airbnb Revenue Nearly Quadrupled in Second Quarter
summary: Home-sharing giant cautions about fall travel even as it projects record revenue for the third quarter. Airbnb Inc.'s second-quarter revenue nearly quadrupled, rebounding from the lows of the pandemic and exceeding pre-pandemic levels, as domestic travel lifted the home-sharing company's fortunes.

title: 'A Brief History of Motion' Review: Rolling Forward
summary: Wheeled vehicles profoundly changed cities-their economies, their design, their hygiene. Innovations in transport continue to do so today.. Tom Standage, the deputy editor of the Economist and one of our best writers of nonfiction, has cultivated a special niche: exploring the history of technology with an eye on both the past and the future. When he finds the right subject-such as the roots and repercussions of digital communication in his 2013 book "Writing on the Wall"-his work is both thought-provoking and scintillating. "A Brief History of Motion: From the Wheel, to the Car, to What Comes Next" isn't quite in the class of its predecessor, but like all of Mr. Standage's books, it is rewarding: the product of deep research, great intelligence and burnished prose. Moreover, he always comes up with offbeat and intriguing facts that I, for one, never knew.

title: Retail's Latest Lures Include Treadmills in the Fitting Rooms and Virtual Legos
summary: Stores have more need than ever to offer experiences that e-commerce can't match. Retailers such as Lego Group and Dick's Sporting Goods Inc. are creating store concepts intended to give shoppers new reasons to visit beyond making a simple purchase.

title: More School Districts in Texas Sue Governor Over Mask-Mandate Ban
summary: The federal government recommends their universal use but most states have left policy creation to local school boards. AUSTIN, Texas-More school districts in Texas are pushing back against an executive order banning mask mandates, joining districts in other states filing lawsuits over the issue.

title: Streatery: Pandemic Dining on Asphalt Gets Its Own Name
summary: A creative solution-and a new portmanteau word-for meals enjoyed in parklets and parking places. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: America's White Population Shrank, Census Data Show
summary: Decennial count indicates Latinos, Asians and other racial groups drove all U.S. population growth during past decade. The first detailed results of the 2020 census show a diversifying nation where the total white population shrank for the first time in its history and where large metropolitan areas, especially in the South and Southwest, saw the strongest growth.

title: VA Health System Won't Cover Biogen's Alzheimer's Drug
summary: Agency cites Aduhelm's risk of serious side effects and a lack of evidence that it improves cognitive function. The Department of Veterans Affairs won't cover Biogen Inc.'s new Alzheimer's drug, the latest rebuke of the controversial treatment since it was approved earlier this summer.

title: Stocks Rise After Jobs Data
summary: Nasdaq rises but stays below record as investors digest earnings from Disney, others. U.S. stocks rose Thursday ahead of a series of earnings reports later in the day and after fresh labor-market data provided insight on the pace of the recovery.

title: 'Respect' Review: The Real Aretha Franklin Is Hard to Beat
summary: Jennifer Hudson leads the star-studded cast in this new biopic about the Queen of Soul.

title: Ushering in the Age of Vax-and-Mask
summary: As Covid-19 continues to surge, will Broadway's new requirements for attendance prove effective?.

title: 'Sparkling: The Story of Champagne' Review: More Dry Than Not
summary: A documentary all about bubbly features interviews with experts and spokespeople from major Champagne houses, with an emphasis on winemaking minutiae.

title: 'The Tempest' Review: Curtain Calls
summary: The Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival bids farewell to its current campus with a superb production of the play thought to be one of Shakespeare's last. Garrison, N.Y.

title: Migrant Border Arrests in July Surge to Highest Level in 21 Years
summary: Nearly 200,000 people were arrested as tens of thousands of families and unaccompanied minors crossed the border. The Border Patrol made about 200,000 arrests at the southern border in July, marking the busiest month at the border in 21 years and a 12% increase over the previous month, according to new figures released by U.S. Customs and Border Protection on Thursday.

title: Are Covid Fears an Okay Social Excuse?
summary: A behavioral economist answers questions about when to tell the truth in declining an invitation and why it's important to support the arts.. Behavioral economist Dan Ariely uses psychological research to advise on everyday dilemmas. Read more columns here.

title: Do Multiple Ear Piercings Spell Mid-Life Crisis?
summary: Gen X and older millennial women are increasingly splurging on multiple earlobe and cartilage piercings. Some are awakening long-dormant wild streaks. Others are reasserting their identities.. IT'S 11 A.M. on a Tuesday when the needle slides cleanly through my flesh. I am in the back room of Ink Side Out tattoo parlor in Norwalk, Conn., with a new friend by my side. In lieu of Pilates or lattes, we-two mothers of a combined seven children-are getting third and fourth holes in our earlobes shortly after camp drop-off. It feels, to this 39-year-old writer, like dancing on the edge.

title: Montana Ranch Andie MacDowell Once Owned Lists for $7.775 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. A Montana ranch once owned by actress Andie MacDowell is listing for $7.775 million.

title: Jewel Case (Friday Crossword, August 13)
A Montana Ranch Built for Entertaining
summary: Once owned by actress Andie MacDowell, the property can sleep 30 across its structures.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Tether Sheds Light, but Not Enough, on Its $63 Billion Reserves
summary: The stablecoin has secured itself a critical place in the crypto ecosystem, but its holdings fall short compared with those of prime money-market funds. One of the things most cryptocurrency enthusiasts really don't want is more exposure to the U.S. government. It turns out-via the biggest so-called stablecoin, tether-that is exactly what they got. Holdings of Treasury bills backing tether surged, according to the first accountant-verified breakdown of its issuer's $63 billion of assets.

title: Summit Partners Targets $7 Billion for Latest Growth Strategy
summary: The new investment pool would be 43% larger than its $4.9 billion predecessor, which closed in 2019. Summit Partners has hit the fundraising circuit with its 11th flagship growth strategy barely a year after it collected more than $2.2 billion across vehicles focused on European growth equity investments and venture capital deals.

title: Home Prices Jumped Across the U.S.
summary: National Association of Realtors numbers show supply of existing homes for sale can't keep up with demand. Home prices surged in almost every corner of the U.S. in the second quarter as robust demand continued to overwhelm the supply of homes for sale.

title: Delta Variant Dents Oil Demand Recovery While OPEC Expects More Supply
summary: Rising OPEC+ supply and new Covid-19 restrictions ease global supply crunch fears, the IEA says. The economic impact of the Covid-19 Delta variant and rebounding output mean that expectations of global oil demand outstripping supply are fading, the IEA and OPEC said Thursday.

title: The Fall Dress That's Just as Ideal in August as September
summary: The classic shirt dress works equally well on vacation in late summer and in the boardroom come autumn. SARAH RUTSON is busy packing to move from Los Angeles to London, and the only clothing not boxed are eight shirt dresses she plans to wear until her flight in early September. The style is a standby for the fashion insider. "I probably have 25 of them in my wardrobe," she said. "When I spot a good one, I don't think twice about buying it." When I called her, she was wearing a 20-year-old Chanel version in blue with white pinstripes, belted with the sleeves rolled up. The dress is an urbane workhorse: That day alone she wore it to the eye doctor, to pick up dry cleaning and to afternoon tea at a swanky hotel.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended August 7
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: Break Out of the Student Loan Forbearance Mindset
summary: Politicians promote poor decision-making and offer handouts as remedies.. Regarding "Student Loan Forbearance-Forever?" (Review & Outlook, Aug. 9): The push to forgive student-loan debt promotes the wrong ideals. My sister and I were fortunate to obtain four-year degrees and graduate without student-loan debt. We could do so because it was our father's goal to fund our educations.

title: Tenants Take Advantage of the CDC's Eviction Ban
summary: In New York, the extension is a moot point.. Regarding "Brett Kavanaugh's Eviction Lesson" (Review & Outlook, Aug. 5): I rent individual apartments of 400 to 500 square feet, mainly to singles, and I have lost thousands of dollars to the eviction moratorium. The younger renters take advantage; the older renters not so much.

title: Dogs Deserve Better Treatment
summary: Pet ownership isn't for everyone.. Pet ownership comes with responsibility ("I'm Disciplining My Dog, Not Torturing Her" by Mark Naida, op-ed, Aug. 3). Training a dog, like raising a child, requires commitment. This is not for everyone-and apparently not for Mr. Naida. With a good trainer, a dog can be trained and housebroken in a timely manner. The habit of "pulling on the leash" usually can be cured in a day or two in a humane manner that does not involve the infliction of pain. If a human is unwilling to invest the time and money into working with and training a dog, then perhaps pet ownership is not for that human.

title: The Climate-Change Cop-Out Is a Politician's Best Friend
summary: Global warming means it's never your fault.. Like Bjorn Lomborg, I believe "Climate Change Doesn't Cause All Disasters" (op-ed, Aug. 6). It is a factor in many, but not the only factor. So why do local politicians seemingly always respond to disasters by emphasizing the role of climate change and promise to "do more" to cut emissions? Greenhouse emissions are a global problem, and local efforts will be swamped by China's and India's coal usage. Plus, any potential good from lowering emissions is decades away.

title: Teachers Weren't Paid Like Essential Workers This Year
summary: Instead of a raise for showing flexibility during an unprecedented and difficult year, we lost pay.. My school district currently has 200 unfilled special-education positions and is lacking more than 200 bus drivers. I am awaiting the day when the market will pay educators as essential workers, since we all saw last year that the economy shuts down without them. I suggest wage experimentation in the school district will work to recruit and retain educators just as it worked to find and keep machine operators in Cleveland ("The Wage Wager," Exchange, Aug. 7).

title: Say Her Name
summary: Ella French was one of Chicago's finest.. As Chicago continues to suffer the violence that has become a predictable result of so-called progressive governance, the city is mourning a dedicated public servant. Megan Crepeau, Stephanie Casanova and Paige Fry report in the Chicago Tribune:

title: Former Media Executive Agrees to Plead Guilty in Varsity Blues College Admissions Scandal
summary: Prosecutors accused Elisabeth Kimmel of paying corrupt college counselor $525,000 to get her children into Georgetown and USC. BOSTON-Elisabeth Kimmel, a former media executive from La Jolla, Calif., has agreed to plead guilty for her role in a nationwide college-admissions scandal, heading off a trial that was scheduled to begin next month.

title: Justice Department Appoints Foreign Bribery Chief
summary: David Last, who was made acting head of the DOJ's Foreign Corrupt Practices Act unit in April, has been given the job on a permanent basis. The U.S. Department of Justice has appointed David Last chief of a high-profile unit that investigates and prosecutes companies for paying bribes to public officials overseas.

title: What to Know About Breakthrough Infections, Cases and Symptoms
summary: Doctors say these infections are rare and generally mild, thanks to vaccines. As the highly transmissible Delta variant spreads, more vaccinated Americans are reporting they have tested positive for Covid-19. Here's what you need to know about these so-called 'breakthrough' cases:

title: Israel Suffers Another Covid-19 Surge
summary: Country delivers more booster shots, restores mask and quarantine mandates as Delta variant drives up hospitalizations. TEL AVIV-After becoming one of the first countries to open up thanks to a widespread Covid-19 vaccination campaign, Israel is again on guard, this time against the spread of the Delta variant of the coronavirus.

title: Coffee Jolt Gets Pricier as Costs Rise
summary: Cafes and retailers lift prices, while others try to hold the line; 'Consumers will be looking for more affordable options'. Many coffee drinkers can expect to pay more for their cup of joe at supermarkets and cafe registers, as producers grapple with higher coffee bean prices, constrained supplies and other costs.

title: What Bosses Can Do to Reduce Anxiety Among Returning Workers
summary: Our survey indicates that a lot of employees are anxious. It also points to what they're anxious about.. As organizations make plans to bring their employees back to the office, they would do well to remember this: Many of those workers are anxious.

title: Afghan Taliban Seize Herat, Continue Advances
summary: Police detain governor of Ghazni province for surrendering its capital to the insurgents. KABUL-The Taliban conquered western Afghanistan's main city of Herat on Thursday and edged close to capturing the southern city of Kandahar, as Afghan police arrested the governor of the strategic Ghazni province for surrendering its capital city to the insurgents earlier in the day.

title: The Danger of Shrinking American Naval Power
summary: China may invade Taiwan within six years, admirals warn. Is the U.S. ready?. The Chinese military will likely attack Taiwan within six years, Adm. Phil Davidson, commander of U.S. Indo-Pacific Command, told Congress in March, just before retiring from the Navy. More generally, he said, Beijing's long-term objective-supplanting the U.S. and remaking the global order to benefit the Chinese Communist Party-will feature confrontation.

title: You're Already Paying for That $4.5 Trillion
summary: Taxes haven't gone up yet, but inflation and lost productivity amount to financial repression.. It's a $4.5 trillion week in Washington. Between the infrastructure and reconciliation bills in various stages of debate, it's worth discussing in some depth how all this will be paid for. Government spending is conventionally understood as a matter of increased taxation and debt, a framing that has the virtue of being true. But that conversation is incomplete without also exploring the concept of financial repression-which ultimately underlies both the taxes and debt.

title: Rand Paul Belatedly Discloses Wife's Purchase of Covid-19 Drugmaker's Stock
summary: Kentucky senator's wife bought stock in Gilead Sciences, maker of remdesivir, in February 2020. WASHINGTON-Sen. Rand Paul disclosed that his wife purchased stock in Gilead Sciences Inc. in late February 2020, the same day the company formally announced that it would start late-stage studies of its experimental treatment for Covid-19 in an acceleration of its push to evaluate the drug, remdesivir.

title: Door County Lives Up to Its Nickname as the Midwest's Cape Cod
summary: Resume Subscription. Dallas venture capitalist Ed Mello has fond memories of idyllic summers spent on Cape Cod in his native Massachusetts and more recent memories of oppressive summers at home in North Texas. In the midst of last summer's lockdowns, Mr. Mello, 63, and his wife, Nancy Mello, a 61-year-old financial adviser, began longing for a northern getaway.

title: A Guide to the New Workday Lunch-And How Much It's Going to Cost
summary: As we inch back to office life and renegotiate working remotely in the months to come, what will the midday meal look like? Tips on emerging trends, how to get the most out of the lunch hour and what we can expect to pay.. ON HIS FIRST DAY back in his New York City office in July, Syed Ali found his biggest challenge, oddly, was lunch. After months of reheating leftovers to eat during Zoom calls, he was looking forward to a sit-down culinary adventure. Sadly, two of his go-to lunch spots had closed. The local outpost of salad chain Sweetgreen was still there but only allowed for online orders. In the end, Mr. Ali, an urban planner, spent most of his break wandering the still mostly empty streets near his Tribeca workplace before finally grabbing a sandwich to eat back at HQ.

title: Adidas to Sell Reebok to Authentic Brands
summary: The value of the deal with the brand-management company is put at roughly $2.5 billion. Adidas AG said it has agreed to sell Reebok to Authentic Brands Group for up to about $2.5 billion, roughly 15 years after acquiring the U.S. fitness brand and trying to revamp it.

title: New Zealand to Pursue Zero-Covid Policy Indefinitely
summary: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern's government might ease entry for fully vaccinated travelers in early 2022 if conditions warrant. New Zealand said it won't loosen its stringent border-control and quarantine procedures until next year as it doubles down on its zero-Covid-19 approach to the pandemic, with plans to consider for entry only vaccinated travelers from low-risk countries starting in early 2022.

title: How the Berlin Wall Rose in a Single Night
summary: Sixty years ago, East Germany's leader secretly stockpiled 150 tons of barbed wire and put his plans in sealed envelopes to be opened just hours before the operation began. When the Berlin Wall came down in November 1989, it was one of the most thoroughly documented events in history. Each anniversary, TV networks replay footage of Germans dancing on the wall and hacking into it with hammers.

title: Afghans Tell of Executions, Forced 'Marriages' in Taliban-Held Areas
summary: In public statements, the Islamist militant group has pledged it wouldn't seek vengeance against government officials and troops. KABUL-Taliban leaders have publicly pledged to be magnanimous in victory, assuring government officials, troops and the people of Afghanistan that they have nothing to fear as ever larger swaths of the country fall under their control.

title: Verandas Bring Things Outside, But Not Too Much
summary: These roofed porches were originally built to help keep homeowners cool. Now they're just nice to sit on. Any time you have a transitional space between the yard and the house it's a great thing, said Todd Pritchett of Pritchett + Dixon, a residential architecture firm in Atlanta. In this case, the transitional space he's referring to is a veranda.

title: How Families Can Keep That Pandemic Togetherness
summary: During lockdown, many families felt closer than ever. They don't have to lose the good stuff.. Amid the fear, loneliness and heartache of the pandemic, there was also a guilty pleasure for many families: They had never been closer. Whether doing puzzles, watching TV shows, eating meals or simply taking walks, parents and children got to spend time together that never seemed possible before Covid.

title: What Climate Change Might Do to Your Favorite Wine
summary: Many oenophiles take particular pleasure in teasing out the nuances of terroir, the specific combination of soil, topography and climate that makes a wine unique. But what happens when extreme weather events and rising temperatures hit a wine region?. THE FRENCH TERM terroir has been defined in various ways-and called undefinable, too-but it's generally understood to denote a combination of soil, topography and climate that gives a wine its particular character. With so many wine regions flooded or on fire in recent months and years, I've wondered: Does this change their terroir?

title: The Perils of Canyon Gazing With Canines
summary: Friendly dogs on high vistas can leave you bungee-jumping without a cord. Last month I was standing on a massive rock with a fabulous view of a seemingly bottomless canyon just outside Grand Junction, Colo., when I heard the unmistakable sound of a large dog approaching.

title: Regal Cinemas' Owner Can't Count on AMC's Meme Crowd
summary: London-listed movie-theater chain Cineworld is considering a U.S. listing to fix its debt-heavy capital structure. Hollywood directors can't intentionally make cult movies, and companies can't set out to create meme stocks. But there's no harm in trying.

title: GameStop's Power Player: How Outsider Ryan Cohen Wrested Control
summary: Resume Subscription. It took just a few months for a 36-year-old entrepreneur to take over America's most talked-about company-and make $1 billion for himself in the process.

title: Simply White, Snowfall White, School House White: Proliferation of White Paint Shades Stupefies Renovators
summary: Resume Subscription. When Christopher Lyon walked into his Washington, D.C., home during his last renovation, he saw red.

title: Potato Farmer Provided Early Funding for Micron Technology
summary: Allen T. Noble, who has died at age 92, pioneered irrigation systems and backed an Idaho maker of semiconductors. When they were forming Micron Technology Inc. in the late 1970s, the founders of the Boise, Idaho, maker of semiconductors didn't seek their initial funding from venture capitalists in Silicon Valley. Instead, they sat down with a potato farmer, a rancher and a building contractor in Idaho.

title: The World of Olympic Water Sports Still Looks Very White. There's a Push to Change That.
summary: Water sports were among the organizations who looked at their record on racial diversity-and promised to do better. Like many children raised in sweltering South Florida, Ashleigh Johnson learned to swim out of necessity because her family had a pool in their backyard. She picked up water polo by chance: she and her four siblings had boundless energy and the local recreational pool happened to offer youth lessons.

title: U.S. Jobless Claims Fell to 375,000 Last Week
summary: New claims fell to 375,000, a sign of labor market momentum despite Delta variant uncertainty. New applications for jobless benefits declined for the third straight week, showing the labor market continues to heal despite worries about the Delta variant.

title: Fliers Offer Fixes for Pains of Air Travel
summary: WSJ readers call for more-flexible cancellation rules, better seating and other enhancements in response to the Middle Seat column on a Passenger Bill of Rights. A recent Middle Seat column by Scott McCartney explored the limited rights customers have when dealing with airlines. We asked readers to submit their own ideas for a Passenger Bill of Rights, and more than 300 responded. Here are some of the most common suggestions.

title: Bill Gates Pledges $1.5 Billion for Infrastructure Bill's New Climate Projects
summary: A Gates-backed venture would apply for matching funds from an Energy Department program that embraces industrial policy. Microsoft Corp. co-founder Bill Gates said his climate investment fund will commit $1.5 billion for joint projects with the U.S. government if Congress enacts a program aimed at developing technologies that lower carbon emissions.

title: Clover Health, Palantir, Coupang: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Occasional meme stock Clover Health was soaring premarket after its earnings report. Stock futures wavered after data showed new applications for jobless benefits, a proxy for layoffs, fell last week. Here's what we're watching before the opening bell.

title: For $2 Million, a Chance to Spend Eternity Next to Marilyn Monroe and Hugh Hefner
summary: At Pierce Brothers Westwood Village Memorial Park in Los Angeles, an unused burial crypt is being shopped by the family of the late Broadway composer Jerry Herman. This is real estate to die for.

title: A 'Ted Lasso' Christmas Episode in August-Why?
summary: Resume Subscription. How did one of television's biggest hits end up giving viewers a Christmas episode in August? Thank Apple.

title: CDC Director Cites Politics, Mistrust as Pandemic Communication Hurdles
summary: 'My job is to put my head down, ignore the criticism and do the right thing for the public,' Rochelle Walensky said in an interview. Rochelle Walensky said the patients she treated as a physician generally trusted that she was working in their best interests. As director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Walensky said she has learned the same isn't always true of many people in the U.S.

title: Kathy Hochul Says She Will Run For New York Governor in 2022
summary: Andrew Cuomo successor also says she will consider mask mandates in New York schools to combat Covid-19. New York Lt. Gov. Kathy Hochul said she would run for governor in the state's 2022 race, making her the first Democrat to announce her plans for the office since Gov. Andrew Cuomoannounced his resignation.

title: A Star Chef's Top-Down Revolution for Solving Food Inequity
summary: Chef Magnus Nilsson left his two-Michelin-star restaurant to help lead the MAD Academy in Copenhagen. Can Scandinavia's farm-to-table ethos bring on a global transformation?. On a stiflingly warm June morning in the Danish capital, the MAD Academy's welcome breakfast is underway. It's the inaugural course and the first full day of operations in its new headquarters, a former gunpowder warehouse bearing the sparse, airy hallmarks of the architect who redesigned it, Bjarke Ingels. Artichoke flowers bundled with twine adorn the shelves alongside sloping bare-wood fixtures, unmoored from the wall to allow future redesigns.

title: CEO of World's Largest Pork Producer Steps Down
summary: Former head of WH Group will remain chairman and an executive director. The billionaire boss of WH Group Ltd. , the Chinese pork producer that bought Virginia-based Smithfield Foods back in 2013, on Thursday relinquished the top job at the company.

title: New Jersey's Best Weekend Getaways Are Even Better This Summer
summary: Resume Subscription. NEW JERSEY'S classic boardwalks and sandy beaches scream summer-sometimes too loudly, when it seems people from all surrounding states are elbowing in to block the view. This summer, because of pandemic adaptations that are being carried into the future, some of the best attractions that were previously "walk-in only" (or don't walk in, because there's a wait) are operating by timed-entry or reservations, making them counterintuitively easier to visit for those who plan ahead. Here are three trips with a twist: a cultural tour of Cape May, a peek at the western Jersey wilderness and a jaunt up the Hudson River from vibrant Jersey City to Edgewater.

title: Millennials' High-Earning Years Are Here, but It Doesn't Feel That Way
summary: Resume Subscription. The oldest millennials are approaching a new money milestone: their high-earning years.

title: Who's Winning the Dodgers-Padres Battle In the NL West? The Giants
summary: San Francisco has unexpectedly emerged with the best record in baseball, disrupting the expected season-long showdown between Los Angeles and San Diego. Brandon Crawford has won two World Series during his career, so he has a good idea of what an elite roster looks like. Even he admits that he wasn't immediately convinced that the 2021 San Francisco Giants qualified.

title: Global ETF Assets Hit $9 Trillion
summary: Net flows so far this year have nearly eclipsed the $736.5 billion investors had moved into ETFs globally in all of 2020. Investors poured $705 billion into exchange-traded funds through the first seven months of the year, pushing 2021's world-wide tally to a record $9.1 trillion, according to data from Morningstar Inc.

title: Facebook's Takeover of Giphy Raises Competition Concerns, U.K. Says
summary: Regulator says the social-media giant could be required to sell the animated-GIF provider. U.K. antitrust officials said they could call on Facebook Inc. to unwind its acquisition of Giphy, a provider of popular animated images, after provisionally finding that the deal would harm competition between social-media platforms and in the display advertising market.

title: Bumble, Match Have Love Left to Give
summary: Investors who have cooled on online-dating stocks like Match and Bumble will be lured back soon enough. Online-dating companies might look like scorned lovers in the stock market these days, but that doesn't mean they won't find their happily ever after.

title: Cuba's Black Communities Bear the Brunt of Regime's Crackdown
summary: Communist officials say the instigators of recent protests are criminals from the island's underworld. Recent antigovernment protests in Cuba were the biggest in more than six decades. But they were historic, too, because many of the protesters were Black Cubans, a group that is increasingly breaking with the country's Communist government.

title: OxyContin Maker Purdue's Chapter 11 Trial to Test Limits of Bankruptcy Powers
summary: Purdue Pharma will seek approval of a settlement with its Sackler family owners with support from most states and opposition from a few. The company most often blamed for the opioid epidemic, OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP, sought refuge in bankruptcy from an onslaught of lawsuits that threatened to put the drugmaker out of business.

title: BlackRock, Others Target Climate Issues and Board Seats in Shareholder Votes
summary: Strength of index-tracking funds sets the stage for future showdowns over issues from director seats to climate-change disclosure. BlackRock Inc. and other heavyweight investors were more willing to flex their muscles against companies in the past year, setting the stage for future showdowns over issues from board seats to climate-change disclosure.

title: Advance Auto Parts Can Keep the Good Times Rolling
summary: America's aging car fleet will keep cash registers ringing at this retailer. This column is part of the Heard on the Street Stock Picking Contest. You're invited to play along with us here.

title: Finance Firms Back Push to Diversify Wall Street
summary: Bloomberg, Centerbridge also part of multimillion-dollar CUNY initiative targeting training, internships and hiring. Bloomberg LP, Centerbridge Partners LP and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. are funding a new program to train, mentor and hire students for careers in the financial sector in a push to bring more women and minorities to the industry.

title: Scarlett Johansson and the Debate Over Streaming Pay
summary: The way studios compensate talent has been messy since Covid-19 pushed subscription services to the forefront in Hollywood. Scarlett Johansson isn't the only movie star with concerns about how Hollywood's focus on streaming could affect her pay. She's just the one that went public.

title: 'Who's Next' Celebrates 50 With Little Fanfare
summary: Fifty years on, The Who's most popular album seems more relevant than ever, despite the troubled fortunes of 'Lifehouse,' the rock opera from which it was born..

title: Evergrande's Enormous Bill Finally Comes Due
summary: China's most indebted property company is selling off strategic assets, but that probably isn't enough to save it. The troubles of China's most indebted property developer are still far from over.

title: 'CODA' Review: The Bounds of Silence
summary: In this film on Apple TV+, co-starring Marlee Matlin, a teenager is torn between her responsibilities as the only hearing member of her family and her wish to nurture her talent for singing. In music, a coda is an ending that's also a variation on the established theme, an unexpected send-off. CODA, on the other hand, stands for Child of Deaf Adults, the one in Siân Heder's film "CODA" being Ruby Rossi (Emilia Jones), a high schooler for whom music is everything. Is her trajectory going to be a shock? No. But what is surprising is the moving, even heartbreaking, way writer-director Heder tells Ruby's story without resorting to clichéd characterizations or syrupy sentimentality.

title: 'Money Court' Review: Mr. Wonderful Rules
summary: Kevin O'Leary of 'Shark Tank' judges financial disputes on CNBC's new law-based reality show. Businessman and "Shark Tank" fixture Kevin O'Leary may refer to himself as "Mr. Wonderful," but he does bring a sobering degree of knowledge and disinterest to CNBC's "Money Court," the latest variation on legal TV and the noble traditions of Judge Joseph Wapner and Judge Judy. Finance is the name of the game, such as it is, and it's not only a more serious version of the law-based reality show but virtually begs a viewer to fill in the inevitable holes in the stories.

title: 'The Lord of Cries,' 'A Midsummer Night's Dream,' 'The Marriage of Figaro' and 'Eugene Onegin' Reviews: Al Fresco Arias
summary: The Sante Fe Opera's scaled-down summer season includes one world premiere and three classics, performed and produced to varying degrees of success.. Santa Fe, N.M.

title: Europe's Electrification Stalwarts Go Digital
summary: The companies that built last century's power grid are preparing for a more high-tech build out in the next wave. Siemens , ABB and Schneider Electric were at the heart of electrifying society last century. In the new age of electrification, they have a different focus: digital technology.

title: Vaccine Hesitancy, Rise in Covid-19 Patients Frustrate Doctors
summary: 'It's too late for them to get the vaccine,' an ICU nurse in Arkansas said. 'It's been pretty demoralizing.'. Some healthcare workers say the latest surges in Covid-19 are adding to fatigue and burnout. But this time exhaustion is amplified by something new: frustration over the insufficient uptake of vaccines that could have prevented most Covid-19 patients from landing in their care.

title: Frackers, Shippers Eye Natural-Gas Leaks as Climate Change Concerns Mount
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON COUNTY, Pa.-Drones darted in patterns above natural-gas wells in the hills of southwest Pennsylvania, as workers atop water tanks pointed specialized cameras, and a helicopter outfitted with a laser-light detection system swooped in low. All searched for an invisible enemy: methane.

title: High-Speed Trader Jump to Execute Retail Investors' Stock Trades
summary: Plan for retail wholesaler business comes as meme-stock frenzy fuels surge in trading by individual investors. Jump Trading Group, one of the world's largest high-frequency trading firms, will launch a unit that executes stock orders for individual investors, a business that has grown more lucrative for electronic traders as meme-stock mania has fueled a surge in U.S. retail volumes.

title: Vaccine Scammers Target Authorities in Dozens of Countries
summary: Criminal groups and individuals have proposed contracts for millions of dollars to officials; vaccine makers say they don't use intermediaries and will sell only directly to governments. Criminal organizations and individuals claiming access to Covid-19 vaccines have contacted authorities in dozens of countries hoping they will sign illegitimate contracts for millions of dollars, according to documents and people familiar with the attempts.

title: Contact Center Software Startup Talkdesk Raises $230 Million
summary: New financing values company at $10 billion. Talkdesk Inc., a provider of cloud-based customer service software, has raised $230 million in a Series D funding round that values the company at $10 billion, up from a valuation of $3 billion in July 2020.

title: Sex-Toy Makers Merge in $1.2 Billion Deal
summary: Companies together expect to generate over $400 million in revenue this year, making it world's biggest sexual wellness company. The closely held European-based companies behind Fifty Shades of Grey vibrators and other sexual wellness brands said they have agreed to merge in a deal that values the combined company at around $1.2 billion, amid increasing global demand for sex toys fueled in part by the pandemic.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: FDA Moving Toward Decision Authorizing Booster Shot for Immunocompromised
summary: Agency could authorize the booster to bolster the virus-fighting defenses of people who have a weaker antibody response to the typical Covid-19 vaccine dose. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration is nearing a decision to authorize Covid-19 booster shots for certain people with weak immune systems, people familiar with the matter said, a shift in the American vaccination strategy as the Delta variant drives up cases of infection.

title: IPCC Climate Change Report Shows Less Cause for Panic-But More Urgency to Act
summary: U.N. panel's study suggests both lower risk of dramatic increases in temperature and higher risk from inaction. The conclusion of the latest report by the United Nations advisory body on climate-that temperatures are rising, and some effects are irreversible-wasn't surprising. Those views are largely in line with its latest report, in 2013.

title: Dominion's Suits Against Trump Allies Can Proceed, Judge Rules
summary: Voting-machine company alleged that Sidney Powell, Rudy Giuliani and MyPillow's Mike Lindell defamed it relating to the 2020 election. WASHINGTON-A federal judge ruled that Dominion Voting Systems Corp. can proceed with three lawsuits alleging that lawyers and supporters of former President Donald Trump defamed the company with false accusations that it rigged the 2020 election.

title: Jan. 6 Panel's Hiring of Homeland Security Official Draws Scrutiny
summary: A committee investigating the Capitol assault appointed an official who oversaw intelligence office, which failed to report warning signs. A Homeland Security official's appointment to the congressional committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol has generated criticism from current and former government officials because of his role overseeing a DHS intelligence office that didn't act on warning signs.

title: California Teachers Must Be Vaccinated or Tested Weekly for Covid-19
summary: First-in-the-nation rule garners support from unions and comes amid nationwide disagreements over Covid-19 safety rules in schools. LOS ANGELES-California will require all schoolteachers and staff to show proof of vaccination or submit to regular coronavirus testing, Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday, becoming the first state in the nation to impose such a requirement on all employees at public and private schools.
